docs.lead_paragraph: Who would have guessed that the lawyers could beat the doctors in a political fight? Not the doctors, evidently. Dressed in their white coats, the doctors turned out for the second time this year to demonstrate at the State House a few days ago for a law to limit the amount that malpractice insurers would have to pay in pain and suffering awards. The doctors claim they are being driven out of the state by high -- and still rising -- premiums.

headline.main: The Doctors Could Use Some Acting Lessons

docs.abstract: Iver Peterson On Politics column on reasons why doctors in New Jersey have not yet succeeded in persuading legislature to pass law limiting malpractice awards (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HUNDREDS of lab-coated doctors rallied on Long Island on Tuesday to protest high liability insurance rates and call for a cap on pain-and-suffering awards in malpractice cases. Physicians and medical staff carried signs and listened to speeches from colleagues in specialties like radiology, obstetrics and neurosurgery who talked about risk, rising costs and diminishing rewards to a smattering of applause. The demonstrations, held simultaneously at Eisenhower Park in East Meadow and Hecksher Park in Huntington, were part of a statewide protest organized by the Medical Society of the State of New York.

headline.main: Doctors Seek to Cut Malpractice Awards

docs.lead_paragraph: RICHARD B. TURAN, president and chief executive officer of the Nassau University Health Care Corporation, excused himself from a recent meeting in his office to huddle with two of his top assistants. He returned a few minutes later to say the county police had arrested someone who needed psychiatric treatment and the police wanted to bring him to the Nassau University Medical Center's emergency room, which the corporation operates and which has the only locked unit in Nassau County.
docs.abstract: Article on important role that Nassau University Medical Center plays in caring for psychiatric and indigent patients as it struggles to survive financially; Nassau University Health Care Corp's nonprofit medical center reportedly will run out of cash unless substantial changes are made; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In just 23 years, Whole Foods Market has grown from a single store in Austin, Tex., to the largest natural foods chain in the nation. It is widely praised for its folksy style and high-quality goods, offering more than 20 kinds of granola, well-stocked wine shelves, attentive service and a hearty bow to Mother Earth. John Mackey, the chairman and chief executive, founded the company on the principles of open communication and empowered employees. Whole Foods workers here have found, however, that the principles do not include embracing labor unions.

headline.main: Love the Worker, Not the Union, A Store Says As Some Organize

docs.lead_paragraph: State efforts to obtain big discounts on prescription drugs for uninsured residents got a welcome boost from the Supreme Court this week. The court lifted an injunction that had prevented Maine from implementing an innovative program that will use the state's purchasing power under Medicaid to press the drug companies for discounts on medicine sold to other citizens as well. Although the court rendered no final judgment on the issue, its reasoning in lifting the injunction gives us hope that the states will ultimately be able to use their Medicaid plans as a crowbar to pry broader discounts from the drug industry. The drug companies already give substantial rebates to the states on virtually all drugs purchased through their Medicaid programs for the poor. The program at issue in Maine, known as Maine Rx, seeks to extend such discounts beyond Medicaid, primarily to help residents with little or no insurance coverage for prescription drugs. The state will seek to negotiate rebates on their behalf from the manufacturers, and those rebates will be distributed to pharmacies to compensate them for selling drugs at discounted prices to the uninsured. Any manufacturer that refused to offer rebates would face a stiff penalty -- its drugs could not be prescribed by doctors for Medicaid patients in Maine without ''prior authorization,'' a bureaucratic hurdle that would greatly curtail sales.
docs.abstract: Editorial hails Supreme Court decision lifting injunction that barred Maine from using its purchasing power under Medicaid to press drug companies for discounts for uninsured; notes Court largely rejected drug industry's arguments against program; suggests Maine may have gone too far in not setting income limits

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna, the big health insurance company, and medical leaders said yesterday that their agreement to settle a long-running lawsuit over billing and medical decisions promised a radical change in their often rancorous relationship and better treatment for patients. In the agreement, in which Aetna broke ranks with nine other insurance companies that are still battling the doctors, Aetna said it intended to provide clearer information on coverage for both patients and doctors, speed payments and reduce red tape.

headline.main: Aetna Agreement With Doctors Envisions Altered Managed Care

docs.abstract: Aetna, one of nation's largest health insurers, and medical leaders say their agreement to settle long-running lawsuit over billing and medical decisions promises radical change in their often rancorous relationship and better treatment for patients; Aetna is breaking ranks with nine other insurance companies that are still battling doctors, agreeing to provide clearer information on coverage for both patients and doctors, speed payments and reduce red tape; changes represent significant step by Aetna away from central precepts of managed care, which was originally designed around so-called gatekeepers--administrators who approve or deny coverage for treatments, often for reasons that are obscure both to doctors and patients; agreement does not call for Aetna to change what it covers, or how much it pays for different procedures; but clarity and openness that Aetna is now promising would help doctors and patients better understand their options in advance of treatment; Aetna and doctors think their accord would put competitive pressure on other health insurers to settle one of largest lawsuits in health care industry, arraying almost 700,000 practicing physicians against health insurance companies that provide about 75 percent of health services; agreement is subject to approval by Judge Federico Moreno; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The acting state attorney general, Peter C. Harvey, announced yesterday that 22 people had been indicted on charges that they participated in a ring that staged automobile accidents for insurance fraud. The authorities identified Eric Boyer, 33, of East Orange, as the mastermind. Mr. Boyer, along with 21 others, were charged with conspiracy, health care claims fraud and attempted theft by deception in the indictment, which was handed up May 19. More than $200,000 in insurance claims were submitted in connection with the orchestrated accidents, which occurred between October 1998 and October 1999, the authorities said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Auto Insurance Fraud Ring Broken

docs.abstract: Eric Boyer and 21 others are indicted for staging auto accidents to collect over $200,000 in fraudulant insurance claims in New Jersey (S)

byline.original: By Stacy Albin (NYT) (Compiled by Jennifer Medina)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a bizarre tale of art and commerce with an unusual corporate twist, a sculpture by a celebrated modern artist has once again figured prominently in the life of a former Humana official who became a critic of managed care. Dr. Linda Peeno, a former medical reviewer for Humana, said yesterday that her life was transformed years ago when she was told that a sculpture of a tall, thin, angst-ridden woman by Alberto Giacometti -- which was displayed in the rotunda of the company's pink marble headquarters in Louisville, Ky., from 1987 to 1994 -- cost $488,000.

headline.main: Art, Commerce and a Heart Transplant Denied

docs.abstract: Dr Linda Peeno, health care consultant on ethical questions, says it was Clarence Jones, Humana official and brother of company's chairman, David A Jones, who told her that Giacometti sculpture that company once owned cost it $3.8 million, which she says is 'enough for eight heart transplants'; was struck years ago, when she was medical reviewer for Humana, that she had to deny payment for heart transplant that cost $488,000, what she thought the sculpture cost until Jones, a friend and neighbor, set her straight; has made comparison between art and transplants since leaving company, and Glenn Waldman, Humana lawyer, successfully petitioned judge to force her to reveal source of information; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna and Physician Group Settle Health Care Lawsuit Aetna broke ranks with nine other insurance companies to reach a settlement with a group of doctors on a long-running lawsuit over billing and medical decisions. Under the agreement, Aetna intends to provide clearer information on coverage for both patients and doctors, speed up payments and reduce red tape. These measures, both sides said, are expected to lead to fewer disputes and administrative headaches for doctors, leaving them more time to concentrate on taking care of patients. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: A bill that would bar employers and insurance companies from discriminating against people based on their genetic histories won the unanimous approval of a crucial Senate committee today, breaking a logjam that had held up the measure for six years. The bill, a result of a compromise on Tuesday night by nine senators, including the leaders of both parties, would set new privacy standards for genetic information, to be enforced by the Department of Health and Human Services. The legislation has the support of the White House and Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy G. Thompson.

headline.main: Panel Breaks Logjam for Bill on Employees' Genetic Histories

docs.abstract: Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions unanimously approves bill to bar employers and insurance companies from discriminating against people based on their genetic histories; bill has languished for six years, first because of resistance from insurers and then because Republicans did not want its protections expanded beyond health insurance to include employers (M)
